synonyms: Zone I, II, III Neck Trauma
content.definition: A systematic approach to penetrating neck trauma based on anatomic zones, guiding evaluation strategy and surgical approach. Zone classification helps determine which injuries require mandatory exploration versus selective management with imaging.

zone_I.management: CTA mandatory - difficult surgical access, may need sternotomy/thoracotomy

zone_II.boundaries: Cricoid cartilage to angle of mandible
zone_II.management: Most surgically accessible; historically mandatory exploration, now selective with CTA

zone_III.boundaries: Angle of mandible to skull base
zone_III.management: CTA mandatory - difficult surgical access, may need mandible subluxation

imaging.cta: Primary imaging modality for stable patients without hard signs
imaging.angiography: For endovascular intervention or when CTA equivocal

zone_II: Can extend proximally or distally as needed
zone_III: Mandible subluxation or osteotomy for access

learning_objectives: Define anatomic boundaries of neck zones I, II, III
Identify structures at risk in each zone
Know hard vs soft signs and their management implications
clinical_pearls: Zone II is most surgically accessible - historically mandatory exploration
Zone I and III injuries require CTA - difficult access
Hard signs = OR, Soft signs = CTA + selective workup
Current trend: selective management with CTA for all zones (no mandatory exploration)
